title-group.article-title: Statement on the update of maximum residue levels (MRLs) for copper compounds in light of the EFSA scientific opinion on the re‐evaluation of the health‐based guidance values (HBGVs) and exposure assessment from all sources
title-group.alt-title: Statement on the update of maximum residue levels (MRLs) for copper compounds

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: In compliance with Article 43 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) reviewed the maximum residue levels (MRLs) for copper compounds in light of the EFSA Scientific Committee opinion on the re‐evaluation of the health‐based guidance values (HBGVs) and exposure assessment from all sources. Based on the exposure calculations performed according to three different scenarios, the updated occurrence data and the residues from the new intended uses are not expected to have an impact on the chronic exposure calculations conducted under the framework of the EFSA Scientific Committee assessment. Therefore, the conclusions of the previous assessment by EFSA Scientific Committee are still valid. Since the current copper exposure is expected to cover all sources of copper, including the uses of copper as plant protection products (PPPs), it can be concluded that the authorised PPP uses for copper compounds and the new intended PPP uses present no health risk for the population, including children. Due to copper being also a micronutrient and ubiquitous in the environment, as requested in the mandate, the dietary risk assessment was performed following a different approach than the standard methodology for the dietary risk assessment of pesticide residues in the framework of setting and reviewing MRLs under Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and in the peer review of pesticides under Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009. Therefore, all MRL proposals are suggested for further consideration by risk managers.

The declarations of interest of all scientific experts active in EFSA's work are available at https://open.efsa.europa.eu/experts
Annex A is available under the Supporting Information section.

sec.title: BACKGROUND AND TERMS OF REFERENCE
sec.p: Copper (Cu) is an essential micronutrient for all living organisms, including humans. It is also a regulated product used in both organic and conventional farming pest management.

The active substance “copper compounds” (covering Copper hydroxide, Copper oxychloride, Copper oxide, Bordeaux mixture and Tribasic copper sulphate) is used in Plant Protection Products (PPPs). It was originally included in Annex I to Council Directive 91/414/EEC on 23 April 2009 by means of Commission Directive 2009/37/EC, 1 and subsequently deemed to be approved under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, 2 in accordance with Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 540/2011, 3 as amended by Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 541/2011. The initial approval was granted until 30 November 2016 and restricted to uses only as bactericide and fungicide. Expiration of approval was afterwards extended to 2018 by Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/232.

In 2018, as part of the procedure for the renewal of approval of copper compounds, EFSA carried out the peer review of the pesticide risk assessment (EFSA, 2018a), under Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 844/2012. 4

The renewal of the approval in accordance with Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/1981, was granted until end of 2025 5 but was restricted to the following conditions: the rates of application and number of treatments have been limited to an overall maximum limit of application of 28 kg of copper per hectare over a period of 7 years, in order to minimise the potential accumulation in soil and the exposure for non‐target organisms.

In 2018, in parallel with the peer review for the renewal of the approval, EFSA carried out a review of the existing MRLs for copper compounds under Article 12 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 6 (EFSA, 2018b), considering residue levels resulting from authorised Good Agricultural Practices (GAPs) and from other environmental sources, including the occurrence data previously assessed by EFSA under the MRL application on wild games (EFSA, 2014). Within the framework of this review, EFSA concluded that the chronic exposure to total copper from authorised GAPs as well as from any other sources (background concentrations, uptake from soil, etc) exceeded the ADI for one diet. Copper background levels in wheat and maize, not directly related to the use of copper as plant protection product (PPP), were identified as major contributors to the exposure. For this reason, in the framework of the MRL review, risk mitigation options to reduce the exposure and identify a safe scenario were limited. Following the Article 12 MRL review, the Commission decided not to act to implement the conclusions of the reasoned opinion and to wait for a more extensive assessment of exposure and risks from all sources.

In 2020, the EFSA Scientific Committee was mandated 7 to provide a scientific opinion on an Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) for copper that could be used by the European Commission as a reference value in managing copper‐containing regulated products, and to perform a new estimation of copper intake considering and assessing the contribution from all sources of exposure, including pesticide residues, to the overall intake of copper.

The result of the mandate was a scientific opinion on the re‐evaluation of the existing health‐based guidance values (HBGVs) for copper and exposure assessment from all sources and was adopted in 2022 (EFSA Scientific Committee, 2023). EFSA's Scientific Committee established that there are no health risks below the hepatic copper retention threshold of an intake of 0.07 mg/kg bw per day for the adult population and concluded that the current copper exposure presents no health risk for the population, including children. It also concluded that background copper levels are a significant source of copper and that PPPs are not a major contributor to exposure.

In 2020 and 2022, EFSA also published two reasoned opinions under Article 10 of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on the modification of the existing MRLs for copper compounds in fresh herbs and edible flowers (EFSA, 2020) and in other small fruits and berries (EFSA, 2022). For both assessments, EFSA concluded that the long‐term consumer intake concerns could not be excluded for the intake of copper residues resulting from the intended uses, existing uses and background/monitoring levels. Although residues in the crops under assessment are minor contributors to the overall consumer exposure, a risk management decision has to be taken whether it is appropriate to increase the existing MRLs for these crops, given that a potential consumer intake concern could not be excluded. Pending the adoption of the EFSA Scientific Committee opinion, the MRLs derived under these two assessments were not implemented in EU legislation.

Furthermore, since the finalisation of the Scientific Committee opinion, most recent occurrence data have been submitted to EFSA under the framework of the monitoring programmes across different regulatory domains.

The decision on the renewal of approval of copper compounds is expected as from 2025 and authorised GAPs may change then. However, considering that Member States report difficulties in enforcing the MRLs due to the background levels being higher than the existing EU MRLs, the Commission requested EFSA to carry out without delay an update of MRLs for copper compounds in light of the EFSA scientific opinion on the re‐evaluation of the HBGVs and exposure assessment from all sources, considering as well the most recent occurrence data submitted to EFSA after the finalisation of the scientific opinion.

In accordance with the terms of reference of the mandate, a short consultation with Member States on the draft Statement was conducted in June 2024. During this consultation, one Member State highlighted that for certain commodities, for which EFSA, in the framework of this assessment, proposed lowering the current MRL, additional uses were authorised after the MRL review. These uses are currently covered by the existing EU MRLs, but would no longer be accommodated under the proposed lower MRLs. Consequently, EFSA was mandated by the European Commission to perform an extra ad hoc consultation to gather information from Member States on these additional authorised uses, including supporting residue trials, and incorporate them into the final statement.

sec.title: ASSESSMENT
sec.p: The consumption and concentration data used for the exposure assessment and the results of the chronic dietary exposure to copper are given in Annex A to this statement. Comments received during the Member States Consultations are compiled in the Member States Consultation reports (EFSA, 2024b, 2024c). The details of all additional authorised uses and data submitted by Member States during the ad hoc consultation, together with a conclusion on their relevance for the assessment are presented in the good agricultural practice (GAP) overview excel file. These files are considered key supporting documents and are made publicly available as background documents to this statement.

sec.title: Consumption data
sec.p: Food consumption data from the EFSA Comprehensive European Food Consumption Database (Comprehensive Database) were used for the dietary exposure assessment of copper as described in section 2.2.2.1 of the scientific opinion on the re‐evaluation of the existing health‐based guidance values (HBGVs) for copper and exposure assessment from all sources (EFSA Scientific Committee, 2023). The most updated version of the comprehensive database which was published in December 2022 was used for this statement. Table A.1 in Annex A provides details on the 49 dietary surveys carried out in 22 Member States and covering 84,676 individuals, used for the chronic dietary exposure assessment.

sec.title: Concentration data for the dietary exposure
sec.p: In line with the approach described under section 2.2.2.2 of EFSA Scientific Committee (2023), in this assessment, two types of concentration data were used to assess the updated dietary exposure to total copper from all sources: data extracted from the EFSA Food Composition Database 9 and data extracted from the EFSA occurrence database.

sec.title: EFSA Food Composition Database
sec.p: No updated data were available in the EFSA Food Composition Database since 2023, thus the same dataset of concentration data of copper in food that was used in EFSA Scientific Committee (2023) is considered in the framework of this statement.

sec.title: EFSA occurrence database
sec.p: To address ToR 1, an extraction from the EFSA occurrence database across all regulatory domains (plant protection products, contaminants, feed/food additives, veterinary medicinal products) was performed on 13February 2024.

The occurrence data submission to EFSA follows the requirements of the EFSA Guidance on Standard Sample Description for Food and Feed (EFSA, 2010b) and the EFSA Guidance on Standard Sample Description 2 (EFSA, 2013). Occurrence data are managed following the EFSA standard operational procedures (SOPs) on ‘Data collection and validation’ and on ‘Data analysis of food consumption and occurrence data’.

As of 13 February 2024, 83,068 analytical results for copper were available in the EFSA occurrence database, which were provided by national authorities of 25 Member States (MSs) 10 plus Iceland, Norway and the United Kingdom (UK) 11 between 2004 and 2022. These include the occurrence data for copper considered in ‘The 2022 European Union report on pesticide residues in food’ (EFSA, 2024a).

The same cleaning and selection procedure were implemented as described in section 2.2.2.2 of EFSA Scientific Committee. Of the extracted 83,068 analytical results, those referring to generic ‘copper and derivatives’ (n = 11), to fortified foods (n = 45), with a limit of quantification (LOQ) > 40 mg/kg (n = 2) or outliers (n = 17) were excluded.

In addition, the following analytical results were excluded according to the approach described in the technical report on handling occurrence data for dietary exposure assessments (EFSA, 2021):
Analytical results reported for samples collected through a suspect sampling strategy (n = 1099).
Analytical results reported for pooled samples with missing information on the number of individual samples included in the pooled sample (n = 1).
Analytical results reported for Total Diet Studies (n = 163).

At the end of the data cleaning and validation, 1338 analytical results were excluded and 81,730 analytical results were available for the dietary exposure assessment and for the calculation of MRLs. The number of analytical results available per year and per country in the final dataset are shown in Appendix A. It is noted that 98% of all the analytical results refer to samples collected from 2012 onwards. Germany provided 64% of all analytical results. The uncertainty related to the representativeness and completeness of the available occurrence data in food and drinking water has been considered in the uncertainty analysis performed in the Scientific Committee opinion. It was concluded that the magnitude and the impact of this uncertainty on the calculated exposure is expected to be low (see table D.2 in EFSA Scientific Committee, 2023).

Left‐censored data (results below limit of detection (LOD) or LOQ) were treated using the substitution method as recommended in the ‘Principles and Methods for the Risk Assessment of Chemicals in Food’ (WHO, 2009). This is the same method as indicated in the EFSA scientific report ‘Management of left‐censored data in dietary exposure assessment of chemical substances’ (EFSA, 2010a). The guidance suggests using the substitution method for chemicals likely to be present in food (e.g. naturally occurring contaminants, nutrients and mycotoxins). Based on this method the lower bound (LB), middle bound (MB) and upper bound (UB) concentrations were estimated. The LB was obtained by assigning a value of zero (minimum possible value) to all samples reported as lower than the LOD (< LOD) or LOQ (< LOQ). The UB was obtained by assigning the numerical value of LOD to values reported as < LOD and of LOQ to values reported as < LOQ (maximum possible value), depending on whether LOD or LOQ is reported by the laboratory. The MB was obtained by assigning the numerical value of LOD/2 to values reported as < LOD and of LOQ/2 to values reported as < LOQ (maximum possible value), depending on whether LOD or LOQ was reported by the laboratory.
A mean LB, MB and UB occurrence value was calculated at each level of the FoodEx2 12 classification.
The updated raw occurrence dataset on copper as extracted from the EFSA data warehouse on the 13February 2024 is available at the EFSA Knowledge Junction community on Zenodo. 13

sec.title: Selection of concentrations for the dietary exposure assessment of total copper
sec.p: To estimate the dietary exposure to total copper and address the ToR 3, the mean concentrations were selected from the two types of concentration data (occurrence and composition) described above. For this selection, the mean MB occurrence values were used to reduce uncertainty in the comparison with the composition data for which the treatment of left‐censored data was unknown. For the food categories for which only one of the two types of data were available, the available mean concentration was used in the dietary exposure assessment. For food categories for which both types of data were available, a selection procedure was applied to select the mean concentration considered most reliable as described in section 2.2.2.2 of EFSA Scientific Committee (2023). In general, the occurrence values, where sufficient and reliable, were given priority, as information was available about the sampling of occurrence data, but not for composition data. Specific food subcategories for which there were no occurrence data available were attributed with the concentration of the parent FoodEx2 category where presence of copper could not be excluded (e.g. mean concentration for generic ‘Tomatoes’ was assigned to ‘Cherries tomatoes’).

Table A.2 in Annex A shows the available occurrence and composition data per Foodex2 code. The column ‘Selected concentration’ indicates which concentration value was taken as result of the selection procedure described in section 2.2.2 of EFSA Scientific Committee (2023).

The mean concentrations used for each FoodEx2 code reported in the Comprehensive Consumption Database are provided in Table A.3 in Annex A together with the source of the data (occurrence vs. composition and the specific food category from which it was derived). Overall, 2427 food groups (raw and processed) were covered by the exposure calculations, including drinking water, infant formulae and follow up formulae.

It is noted that the highest mean concentrations used in the dietary exposure assessment were those available for livers of various animals, tree nuts and oil seeds, some molluscs, soy proteins, cocoa products and other infusion ingredients. Mean concentrations ranged from less than 0.01 mg/kg in vegetable fats and oils, and water to more than 100 mg/kg in veal liver.

These mean concentrations are expected to reflect the residues from all sources of copper, including the uses of PPPs that were already authorised at the time of the collection of the occurrence data (i.e. all uses reported under the MRL review and in the present assessment, except for the use on wheat which was only recently authorised).

sec.title: Selection of concentration data to estimate the impact of new PPP uses of copper compounds not yet authorised and the PPP use on wheat only recently authorised
sec.p: New PPP uses of copper compounds were assessed by EFSA through two different MRL applications on fresh herbs and edible flowers and other small fruits and berries, for which reasoned opinions under Article 10 were published (EFSA, 2020, 2022), but not yet implemented in EU legislation. Furthermore, during the ad hoc consultation, a Member State reported one use on wheat that was authorised in December 2023. Since these GAPs were not authorised when the occurrence data were collected, the concentration data selected for the overall dietary exposure assessment to total copper as described under the previous subsection ‘Selection of concentrations for the dietary exposure assessment of total copper’, might not yet reflect the contribution from these uses.

Therefore, for these commodities, results from treated and untreated samples from the GAP compliant trials submitted in the framework of the previous MRL applications (Austria, 2022; Germany, 2018) and as part of this assessment (Poland, 2023) were considered and compared with the mean concentration data selected for the overall dietary exposure assessment to total copper.

To estimate the contribution of copper from these uses to the overall dietary exposure, the median concentrations in control samples and treated samples were compared. In addition, the mean ratio between the concentrations in untreated and treated crops from field trials were calculated.

Table 1 shows the comparison of the copper concentration in untreated and treated crops (wheat grain, herbs and edible flowers and the different commodities belonging to the group of other small fruits and berries) from supervised field trials (mg/kg), the mean ratio of the copper concentration in untreated and treated crops across field trials and the mean copper concentrations selected for the dietary exposure assessment to total copper. It is noted that for azaroles and similar‐ consumption data are not available, and, therefore, the dietary exposure could not be calculated for this commodity; nevertheless, due to the low relevance of azaroles in European diets, this is not expected to have an impact on the overall exposure.

caption.p: Median copper concentration (STMR) in untreated (control) and treated crops from supervised field trials and mean copper concentrations as selected for the dietary exposure assessment to total copper (mg/kg).

fn.p: Abbreviation: STMR, supervised trials median residue.
Copper concentration selected for the dietary exposure assessment of total copper.
N is the number of studies in which a mean ratio was calculated; the mean ratio was calculated from ratio of each individual study.

For azaroles and similar‐consumption data are not available. Therefore the dietary exposure could not be calculated for this commodity; nevertheless, this is not expected to have an impact on the overall exposure.
Concentration data used in the dietary exposure assessment were sourced from the EFSA Food Composition database.

sec.p: The median concentration values of the control samples give an indication of the copper content in the crops when PPPs containing copper are not used. The median concentration values from treated samples reflect the levels of copper expected in crops treated according to the critical GAP.

The ratio ‘control/treated’ is a good indicator of the impact of the use of copper as PPP on the final copper concentration. The mean ratio calculated for wheat (0.72), shows that most of the copper observed in samples from the treated crop is related to the background, suggesting that the contribution of PPPs to the copper concentration in this crop is limited. On the contrary, the mean ratio calculated for herbs and edible flowers (0.13) and for other small fruits and berries (0.53) suggests that PPPs contribute significantly to the overall concentration of copper in these commodities. In particular, residues in control samples of herbs and edible flowers were always below the LOQs of 2 and 5 mg/kg. It is also observed that for herbs and edible flowers and for other small fruits and berries the standard deviation is higher or very close to the mean ratio, indicating that there is a high variability of the ratio among trials.

Furthermore, the comparison between the concentration values observed in samples of supervised field trials (control and treated) with the actual concentration values considered in the exposure calculations (occurrence or composition data), is useful to understand whether the exposure calculations cover the residues from the recently authorised use on wheat and from the new intended uses on herbs and edible flowers and on other small fruits and berries. According to this comparison, the available occurrence data used in the dietary exposure for wheat grain are in line with results in treated samples. Therefore, it can be concluded that the contribution of residues from this authorised use to the overall dietary exposure is expected to be already covered by the concentration data selected for the dietary exposure assessment to copper. This is also the case for rose hips and similar‐ for which the mean occurrence data is higher than the supervised trials median residue (STMR) from the trials. On the contrary, for herbs and edible flowers, elderberries and similar‐, gooseberries and similar‐, blueberries and similar‐, cranberries and similar‐, mulberries (black and white) and similar‐, currants and similar‐, the concentration data selected for the exposure calculations are lower than the median residues measured in treated samples.

Hence, to address ToR 2 and ToR 3, an additional dietary exposure calculation was performed as follows: the mean concentrations for herbs and edible flowers, elderberries and similar‐, gooseberries and similar‐, blueberries and similar‐, cranberries and similar‐, mulberries (black and white) and similar‐, currants and similar‐ selected as described under the subsection ‘Selection of concentrations for the dietary exposure assessment of total copper’ were replaced by the STMR derived from the supervised residue trials assessed in the previous MRL applications (Austria, 2022; EFSA, 2020, 2022; Germany, 2018) and reported in Table 1.

sec.title: Concentration data for the calculation of MRLs
sec.p: In accordance with the ToR 4, two separate lists of MRLs should be derived in the framework of this statement: a list of MRLs calculated from the updated occurrence data (list 1) and a list of MRLs derived from the residue trials supporting the existing uses (list 2).

As requested in the mandate, MRL calculation from updated occurrence data (list 1), was based only on the data obtained from the EFSA occurrence database as described in the ‘EFSA occurrence database’ subsection. Each Foodex2 code was mapped to the relevant code in the Matrix catalogue. The Matrix catalogue contains the groups and the individual products listed for the monitoring of pesticides residues (Part A of Annex I to Reg. 396/2005). MRLs were derived based on this classification.

Finally, although not explicitly requested under ToR 4, MRLs derived under the two MRL applications published after the MRL review and reflecting uses not yet authorised were reported as such in the recommendation table.

sec.title: Exposure assessment
sec.p: To address ToR 3, EFSA considered the results of the chronic dietary exposure to copper performed in EFSA Scientific Committee (2023) (scenario 1) and performed additional calculations considering the updated concentration data (scenario 2) and the new uses on herbs and edible flowers and other small fruits and berries (scenario 3) (see as well chapters in Section 1.2 on the selection of the concentration data for the dietary exposure).

For calculating chronic dietary exposure to copper, food consumption and body weight data at the individual level were obtained from the Comprehensive Database. This database covers over 2500 food groups (raw and processed) including drinking water, infant formulae and follow up formulae and is not limited to the raw individual commodities considered for MRL setting (listed in Part A of Annex I to Reg. 396/2005). The mean daily consumption at the individual level was combined with the mean copper concentration values (scenario 2) or with the SMTR from residue trials (scenario 3) at the most detailed level of the Foodex2 classification system to calculate individual average daily exposures. Based on the distributions of individual average daily exposures, the mean and 95th percentile exposures were calculated per survey and per age class (see EFSA Scientific Committee, 2023 for further details on methodology).

It is noted that this approach deviates from the standard methodology used for the risk assessment of pesticide residues within the framework of setting and reviewing MRLs under Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and in the peer review of pesticides under Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009, which is based on the EFSA Pesticide Residues Intake Model (PRIMo) (covering only the commodities included in Annex I of Regulation 396/2005) and considers the STMR derived from trials compliant with the most critical GAPs.

sec.title: MRL calculation based on updated occurrence data
sec.p:
In accordance with Commission Regulation (EU) No 283/2013, when MRLs are established based on occurrence data, the MRL shall cover the 95th percentile (P95) of the data population at the 95% confidence interval (CI95). To satisfy this requirement, a minimum of 59 14 residue results (number of observations, Nobs) are required per food commodity. Of the 270 food products of the data set (including plants and animal commodities, and honey), this requirement was met for 175. For the remaining commodities, EFSA calculated a tentative MRL based on the highest reliable percentile calculable from the available sample size, according to the following approach:
For commodities with 29 ≤ Nobs ≤ 59, MRL is based on CI95 of P90.
For commodities with 5 ≤ Nobs ≤ 29, MRL is based on CI95 of P50.
For commodities with less than five results (37 in total), no percentiles were calculated.
EFSA calculated the percentiles not only for the individual commodities, but also for all commodity groups (e.g. citrus fruits, tree nuts, etc.).
MRL values were derived rounding the percentiles to the closest MRL class, in line with the rules applied in the OECD MRL calculator (OECD, 2014).

In addition, EFSA calculated the P95 regardless of the sample size. With these estimates, EFSA provided the probability (coverage expressed in %) that the true P95 is smaller than the maximum of reported values for the sample. The lower is the probability (coverage %), the less reliable is the estimated P95. For these estimates, the confidence intervals (CI) were not calculated.

sec.title: MRL calculation from additional authorised uses and supervised residue trials
sec.p: The MRLs based on the additional authorised uses and supervised residue trials submitted during the ad hoc consultation (Czech Republic, 2024; Germany, 2024; Italy, 2024a, 2024b; Poland, 2023) and relevant for this assessment were calculated by using the Organisation for Economic Co‐operation and Development (OECD) MRL calculator (OECD, 2014). The number of residue trials and extrapolations were evaluated in accordance with the European guidelines on comparability, extrapolation, group tolerances and data requirements for setting MRLs (European Commission, 2023).

sec.title: Results of the chronic dietary exposure assessment
sec.p: Table 2 shows the summary statistics of the estimated chronic dietary exposure to total copper (mg/kg bw per day) for each age group across surveys as calculated in EFSA Scientific Committee (2023) (scenario 1). Table 3 shows the summary statistics of the estimated chronic dietary exposure to total copper (mg/kg bw per day) for each age group across surveys using the selected mean concentrations from the composition and the updated occurrence databases as described under Section 1.2 of this statement (scenario 2). Alike, Table 4 displays the summary statistics for the estimated chronic dietary exposure, including the new uses not yet authorised and not expected to be covered by scenario 2 (scenario 3). Detailed mean and 95th percentile (P95) dietary exposure estimates for all age groups and dietary surveys are presented in Annex A (Table A.4).

In scenario 3, mean dietary exposure to copper ranged from 0.014 mg/kg bw per day in adults and elderly people to 0.089 mg/kg bw per day in infants. The 95th percentile of dietary exposure ranged from 0.024 mg/kg bw per day in adults and elderly to 0.155 mg/kg bw per day in infants.

Compared to the calculations performed in EFSA Scientific Committee (2023) (Table 2), mean and P95 exposure ranges derived taking into consideration the updated occurrence data (see Table 3) and the new uses not yet authorised (see Table 4) showed negligible differences. Detailed mean and 95th percentile (P95) dietary exposure estimates for all age groups and dietary surveys including new uses are presented in Annex A (Table A.5).

caption.p: Summary statistics of the chronic dietary exposure to total copper (mg/kg bw per day) across European dietary surveys by age group as calculated in EFSA Scientific Committee (2023) (scenario 1).
Summary statistics of the chronic dietary exposure to total copper (mg/kg bw per day) across European dietary surveys by age group based on updated concentration data (scenario 2).
Summary statistics of the chronic dietary exposure to total copper (mg/kg bw per day) across European dietary surveys by age group including new uses not yet authorised (scenario 3).

sec.title: Results of the MRL calculation based on updated occurrence data
sec.p: A summary of the occurrence data used and the derived MRLs is presented in Appendix B. Data were also available for baby foods and drinking water. For completeness, they are also presented in Appendix B although no MRLs for these commodities are included in the recommendation table (Table 5).

Based on the updated occurrence data, (tentative) MRLs could be calculated for 175 individual commodities (including plants, animals and honey). Since copper concentrations in chia seeds and duck liver were significantly higher than those in their main commodities in Part A of Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 (i.e. buckwheat and poultry liver, respectively) two separate MRLs were calculated for buckwheat (one including and one excluding chia seeds) and for poultry liver (one including and one excluding duck liver). Additionally, MRLs were calculated specifically for chia seeds and duck liver. Risk managers may consider setting MRLs only for the main commodity in Part A (buckwheat and poultry liver) or separate MRLs for the commodities in Part B (chia seeds and duck liver) of Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 396/2005.

Occurrence data from various regulatory domains (plant protection products, contaminants, feed/food additives, veterinary medicinal products) were pooled to calculate the MRLs. It is emphasised that the analytical methods used for copper determination may vary with regards to the sample preparation step, with washing and/or peeling potentially applied to samples reported under the contaminants domain 15 while this practice is not typically applied in the analysis of pesticide residues. Consequently, some MRL values calculated from occurrence data may be underestimated. Nevertheless, it should be stressed that background levels of copper not directly related to the use of copper compounds as PPPs are not expected to be removed by washing/peeling.

For 37 individual commodities, namely chestnuts, coconuts, quinces, medlars, dewberries, cranberries, dates, kumquats, carambolas, litchis/lychees, passion fruits/maracujas, prickly pears/cactus fruits, cherimoyas, guavas, cassava roots/manioc, turnips, okra (lady's fingers), cresses, and other sprouts and shoots, baby leaf crops (including brassica species), watercress, sage, rosemary, thyme, laurel/bay leave, tarragon, globe artichokes, lupins (dry), safflower seeds, valerian root, ginseng root, fenugreek, nutmeg, allspice, juniper berry, sugar canes, sheep fat, horse milk, occurrence data were not enough to derive even a tentative MRL.

Moreover, those 52 individual commodities (loquats/Japanese medlars, mulberries (black and white), azaroles/Mediterranean medlars, jambuls/jambolans, star apples/cainitos, American persimmons/Virginia kaki, breadfruits, durians, soursops/guanabanas, yams, arrowroots, land cresses, red mustards, purslanes, chervil, lentils, cardoons, bamboo shoots, palm hearts, mosses and lichens, cotton seeds, borage seeds, gold of pleasure seeds, castor beans, oil palms kernels, oil palm fruits, kapok, sorghum, black caraway/black cumin, celery, dill, Sichuan pepper, tamarind, horseradish, capers, saffron, mace, chicory roots, edible offals (other than liver and kidney) of swine, bovine, sheep, goat and equine, goat and equine fat, kidney and edible offals from other farmed terrestrial animals, duck, geese and quail eggs, amphibians and reptiles, and terrestrial invertebrate animals) for which no occurrence data at all were available, are not listed in Appendix B.

sec.title: Results of the MRL calculation from additional authorised uses and supervised residue trials
sec.p: The additional authorised uses and residue trials submitted by Member States during the ad hoc consultation (Czech Republic, 2024; Germany, 2024; Italy, 2024a, 2024b; Poland, 2023) and the derived MRLs are reported in Appendix C.

There are no standard studies investigating the storage stability of copper residues in plant matrices. However, as copper is a monoatomic element and inherently stable, it is not expected to undergo degradation during storage. Therefore, residues of copper are expected to be stable in all residue trials samples.

Reported residue trials were sufficient to derive (tentative) MRLs for all crops listed in the Appendix C.2, except for dry peas, for which no residue trials were available. The following considerations are noted: –
Peas (dry): eight trials compliant with the southern outdoor GAP are required.–
Citrus fruits: in the available trials on oranges and mandarins, the minimum interval (days) between applications is shorter (7 days) compared to the GAP for these crops (20 days); however, considering the persistency of copper, this deviation is acceptable and no additional trials compliant with the southern GAP for citrus fruits are required.–
Olives: pending validation data on analytical methods for high‐oil content commodities which was identified as a data gap during the MRL review (EFSA, 2018b), the MRL should be considered tentative only.–
Kaki: trials on kaki compliant with the southern use for this crop were not available. However, based on overdosed trials on apples and pears it is expected that treatment before flowering will not result in residues above the LOQ in this crop. Further residue trials are therefore not required and the MRL can be proposed at the validated enforcement LOQ for high‐water content commodities considered during in the MRL review (i.e. 2 mg/kg).–
Granate apples: trials on granate apples compliant with the southern use were not available and no clear extrapolation rules are given for this minor crop in SANTE/2019/12752 (European Commission, 2023). However, based on overdosed trials on apples and pears it is expected that treatment before flowering will not result in residues above the LOQ in this crop. Therefore, the extrapolation from apples and pears to granate apples is considered acceptable in this case, the MRL can be proposed at the enforcement LOQ for acidic commodities considered during in the MRL review (i.e. 5 mg/kg) and additional trials are not required.–
Kales and Chinese cabbage: although uses on these crops are already authorised, it is noted that, based on the available trials, the derived MRL (30 mg/kg) is higher than the existing one (20 mg/kg).–
Kohlrabies: available trials to support the northern and indoor uses were performed with 4 instead of 6 applications. However, this is deemed acceptable since, according to the GAP, the two missing applications would have been performed in a very early growth stage and their contribution to the final residue is expected to be negligible. Further residue trials are therefore not required.–
Beans (without pods) and lentils (fresh): available residue trials considered to derive the MRLs for these commodities were conducted with four instead of five applications. However, this deviation is deemed acceptable since according to the GAP the first application is done at early growth stage (BBCH 11), and it is not expected to have a significant impact on the final residue levels.
Concerning lentils, no clear extrapolation rules are given for this crop in SANTE/2019/12752 (European Commission, 2023). However, considering that this is a minor crop, the extrapolation from a combined dataset of trials on beans and peas without pods is considered acceptable.–
Sugar beet roots: in the available trials supporting the northern use, the minimum interval between applications is shorter (7 days) compared to the GAP for this crop (14 days); however, considering the persistency of copper, this deviation is deemed acceptable and no additional trials compliant with the NEU use are required.–
Wheat grain: the MRL derived using the OECD calculator (15 mg/kg) is higher than the existing MRL (10 mg/kg) for this crop. Nevertheless, considering that: ◦
all available trials were performed with applications at later growth stages (BBCH 47–65) compared to the authorised GAP (BBCH 30–55) and lower residues are expected, when copper is used according to the authorised use;◦
results from residue trials are very homogenous and the highest measured residue was 4.66 mg/kg;◦
according to the ratio ‘control/treated’ reported under Section 3.1, most of the copper observed in samples from the treated crop is related to the background level of copper in wheat grain;
it is expected that a lower MRL of 7 mg/kg (based on the mean plus 4 times the SD), could be sufficient to cover this use.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
sec.p: Based on the exposure calculations performed in the present assessment according to three different scenarios, the updated occurrence data and the residues from the new intended uses are not expected to have an impact on the exposure calculations performed in the 2023 EFSA Scientific Committee opinion. Therefore, the outcome of the previous EFSA scientific opinion is still considered valid. Since the current copper exposure is expected to cover all sources of copper, including the uses of PPPs and considering the results of the scenario including the new uses, it can be concluded that the existing uses for copper compounds and the new intended uses present no health risk for the population, including children. In line with the ToR 4, EFSA compiled a recommendation table (Table 5) listing the MRLs based on the supervised residue trials as derived in the framework of the MRL review, in subsequent MRL assessments and in the present statement (list 1) and the MRLs derived from occurrence data based on the most updated dataset (list 2). To support the decision‐making process, for those individual commodities for which the number of samples was not sufficient to calculate a reliable percentile (see Section 3.2), EFSA has proposed the MRL calculated for the relevant commodity group. It is noted that, since copper concentrations in chia seeds and duck liver were higher than those in buckwheat and poultry liver, respectively, different MRLs proposals were included in Table 5 for these commodities.

The assessment of analytical methods for enforcement was not requested in the mandate. For the list of MRLs derived from residue trials (list 1), EFSA considered the LOQs for enforcement from the previous MRL review, i.e. 5 mg/kg for high‐acid content and 2 mg/kg for high‐water content commodities and these values can be higher than the calculated MRL from monitoring data (list 2) for certain commodities.

Due to copper being also a micronutrient and ubiquitous in the environment, as requested in the mandate, the dietary risk assessment was performed according to a different approach than the usual methodology used for pesticide residues in the framework of setting and reviewing MRLs under Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and in the peer review of pesticides under Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009, by considering the EFSA comprehensive food consumption database, concentration data from composition and occurrence databases and results from residue trials compliant with the most critical good agricultural practices only for the assessment of new PPPs uses not yet authorised or only recently authorised.
Risk managers can consider either setting the MRLs for copper compounds at the values based on results from supervised residue trials, or at the values derived from occurrence data.

Furthermore, it is highlighted that uncertainty remains regarding the occurrence data for what concerns the preparation of some samples before the analysis under the framework of the different regulatory domains. While this is not expected to have an impact on the reliability of calculated exposure, some of the MRLs based on occurrence data might be underestimated if samples were washed and/or peeled, before analysis (in accordance with EN 13804:2013, updated by EN 17851:2023). Nevertheless, it should be stressed that background levels of copper not directly related to the use of copper compounds as PPPs are not expected to be removed by washing/peeling.

In case risk managers decide to implement the MRLs derived from available residue trials, the following data gaps identified during the MRL review are still considered relevant:
Additional residue trials supporting the GAPs on kiwi fruits, cucurbits with inedible peel, watercress and hops.

If MRLs will be set based on occurrence data, it is recommended to continue monitoring the residues of copper in food, reporting to EFSA information on whether samples were washed and/or peeled before the analysis. Specifically, occurrence data currently available were not sufficient to derive robust MRLs for the following commodities: 2
limes, almonds, chestnuts, coconuts, macadamia, pecans, pistachios, quinces, medlars, loquats/Japanese medlars, blackberries, dewberries, cranberries, gooseberries (green, red and yellow), rose hips, mulberries (black and white), azaroles/Mediterranean medlars, elderberries, group of miscellaneous fruits with edible peel, litchis/lychees, passion fruits/maracujas, prickly pears/cactus fruits, star apples/cainitos, American persimmons/Virginia kaki, papaya, granate apples/pomegranates, cherimoyas, guavas, breadfruits, durians, soursops/guanabanas, group of tropical roots and tuber vegetables, Jerusalem artichokes, parsnips, salsifies, swedes/rutabagas, turnips, shallots, okra (lady's fingers), gherkins, escaroles/broad‐leaved endives, cresses and other sprouts and shoots, land cresses, red mustards, baby leaf crops (including brassica species), purslanes, chards/beet leaves, grape leaves and similar species, watercresses, witloofs/Belgian endives, chervil, sage, rosemary, thyme, basil and edible flowers, laurel/bay leaves, tarragon, beans (without pods), lentils, cardoons, celeries, Florence fennels, globe artichokes, bamboo shoots, palm hearts, mosses and lichens, lupins (dry), mustard seeds, cotton seeds, safflower seeds, borage seeds, gold of pleasure seeds, hemp seeds, castor beans, group of oil fruits, sorghum, hibiscus/roselle, rose, jasmine, lime/linden, mate/maté, herbal infusions from roots, herbal infusions from any other parts of the plant, cocoa beans, carobs/Saint John's breads, hops, anise/aniseed, black caraway/black cumin, celery, coriander, cumin, dill, fenugreek, nutmeg, allspice/pimiento, Sichuan pepper, caraway, cardamom, Juniper berry, vanilla, tamarind, bark spices, root and rhizome spices except turmeric/curcuma, bud spices, flower pistil spices, aril spices, group of sugar plants, sheep fat, goat fat, goat liver, goat kidney, equine fat, equine liver, equine kidney, poultry fat, duck liver, poultry kidney, poultry edible offals (other than liver and kidney), fat and kidney from other farmed terrestrial animals, milk from goat and from horse, eggs from duck, geese and quail.

The following general data gaps are considered relevant for both MRL proposals based on supervised residue trials and occurrence data: 3
Analytical methods for enforcement in commodities with high‐oil content, dry commodities as well as for any other complex matrices (tea, coffee beans, cocoa beans, carobs, hops, herbal infusions and spices);4
Validation of the performance characteristic of the analytical method for enforcement in commodities of animal origin.

It is highlighted that for some commodities, the trials available for the MRL review and in the present assessment were not sufficient to derive an MRL. For these commodities the MRL value proposed in the summary table was based on the occurrence data. EFSA therefore identified the following data gaps which are not expected to impact on the validity of the MRLs derived but which might have an impact on national authorisations:
Residue trials supporting the GAPs on figs, passion fruits, mangoes, cherimoyas, asparagus, cardoons, beans (dry), peas (dry) and lentils (dry), sunflower seeds, rapeseeds, soya beans.
If the above reported data gaps are not addressed in the future, Member States can consider withdrawing or modifying the relevant authorisations at national level.

fn.p: Indicate that the MRL is proposed at the LOQ for enforcement considered when assessing the residue trials in the framework of the MRL review (LOQ = 2 mg/kg for high water content commodities and LOQ = 5 mg/kg for high acid content commodities).

MRL is derived from an existing EU GAP, which is fully supported by data. Available occurrence data allow to derive a robust MRL. Since the current copper exposure is expected to cover all sources of copper, including the uses of copper as plant protection products (PPP), it can be concluded that the existing PPP uses for copper compounds presents no health risk for the population, including children. Due to copper being also a micronutrient and ubiquitous in the environment, the dietary risk assessment was performed following a different approach than the standard methodology for pesticide residues in the framework of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009. Therefore, MRL proposals from trials and from occurrence data are for further consideration by risk managers.

MRL is derived from an existing EU GAP, which is fully supported by data. Available occurrence data allow to derive only a tentative MRL. Since the current copper exposure is expected to cover all sources of copper, including the uses of copper as plant protection products (PPPs), it can be concluded that the existing PPP uses for copper compounds presents no health risk for the population, including children. Due to copper being also a micronutrient and ubiquitous in the environment, the dietary risk assessment was performed following a different approach than the standard methodology for pesticide residues in the framework of Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 and Regulation (EU) No 1107/2009. Therefore, MRL proposals from trials and from occurrence data are for further consideration by risk managers.

In accordance with the Agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland from the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, and in particular Article 5(4) of the Windsor Framework in conjunction with Annex 2 to that Framework, the EU requirements on data sampling are also applicable to Northern Ireland and, for the purpose of this statement, references to Member States include the United Kingdom in respect of Northern Ireland.
Samples from the United Kingdom are included up to sampling year 2020, when the country was still part of the European Union and were thus included in the analysis.
FoodEx2 is a comprehensive food classification and description system developed and maintained by EFSA to cover the needs of data collections in different domains.

fn.p: Abbreviation: n.c., not calculated.

When at least 59 observations were available to derive the percentile 95 (P95), the 95% confidence interval (CI) of P95 is reported. When Nobs ≤ 59, the 95% confidence interval of the highest reliable percentile (HRP) is reported.
MRL values were derived rounding the percentiles to the closest MRL class, in line with the rules applied in the OECD MRL calculator.

P95 (without confidence interval) was calculated for all commodities, regardless of the number of observations. The probability that the true P95 value is smaller than the maximum reported value for the sample (coverage, expressed in %) is also reported (the lower is the probability, the less reliable is the estimated P95).
Calculated MRL driven by left‐censored data (< LOQ), which are higher than the maximum reported measured value.

sec.label: C.3
sec.title: MRL CALCULATION BASED ON ADDITIONAL AUTHORISED USES AND SUPERVISED RESIDUE TRIALS

tr.th: Residue levels observed in the supervised residue trials (mg/kg)

td.p: Trials on oranges and mandarins with application rate within 25% deviation (Italy, 2024b). Trials performed with 7 instead of 20 days interval between applications, deemed acceptable since, considering the persistency of copper, this deviation is not expected to have a significant impact on the final residue levels. Extrapolation to the whole group of citrus fruits is applicable.
Trials on plums compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (France, 2016; Italy, 2024b).

tr.td: Table olives Olives for oil production

td.p: Overdosed trials on table olives (Italy, 2024a). Results were scaled down to target rate. Extrapolation to olives for oil production is applicable.
Combined dataset of overdosed trials (2.2–6.8N) on apples and pears (France, 2016) deemed acceptable since all results were < LOQ. Extrapolation to kaki is applicable.

Combined dataset of overdosed trials (2.2–6.8N) on apples and pears (France, 2016) deemed acceptable since all results were < LOQ. Extrapolation to granate apples acceptable since application is performed before flowering.
Trials on carrots compliant with GAP (Germany, 2024). Extrapolation from carrots to the whole group of other root and tuber vegetable except sugar beets is applicable.

tr.td: Trials on onions with application rate within 25% deviation (Italy, 2024b). Extrapolation to garlic and shallots is applicable.

td.p: Trials on Brussels sprouts compliant with GAP (Germany, 2024).
Trials on head cabbages compliant with GAP (Germany, 2024).

Trials on kales compliant with GAP. Extrapolation to Chinese cabbages is applicable (Germany, 2024). Although trials results are below the existing MRL, it is noted for further consideration by risk managers that the MRL derived is higher than the existing one (20 mg/kg).

Trials on kohlrabi performed with 4 applications instead of 6, deemed acceptable since according to the GAP the first applications are done at early growth stage, and they are not expected to have a significant impact on the final residue levels (Germany, 2024).

Trials on kohlrabi performed with 4 applications instead of 6, deemed acceptable since according to the GAP the first applications are done at early growth stage, and they are not expected to have a significant impact on the final residue levels (Germany, 2024).
Trials on beans with pods compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (France, 2016; Italy, 2024b). Extrapolation to peas with pods applicable.
Trials on beans and peas with pods compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (France, 2016; Italy, 2024b).
Trials on beans and peas without pods compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (France, 2016; Italy, 2024b) used to derive an MRL for peas without pods.
Trials on beans and peas without pods compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (France, 2016; Italy, 2024b) used to derive an MRL for peas without pods.

Trials on beans and peas without pods conducted with 4 instead of 5 applications, deemed acceptable since according to the GAP the first application is done at early growth stage (BBCH 11) and it is not expected to have a significant impact on the final residue levels. Extrapolation to lentils acceptable.
Trials on celeries compliant with GAP. Extrapolation to Florence fennels and rhubarbs is applicable (Germany, 2024).

Trials on sugar beet compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (Czech Republic, 2024; France, 2016; Italy, 2024b). Trials performed with 7 instead of 14 days interval between applications, deemed acceptable since, considering the persistency of copper, this deviation is not expected to have a significant impact on the final residue levels.
Trials on sugar beet compliant with GAP or with application rate within 25% deviation (France, 2016; Italy, 2024b).

Trials on wheat grain conducted at more critical BBCH (65 instead of 55) (Poland, 2023). Considering this, that the dataset is very homogeneous, that the highest residue was 4.66 mg/kg, and that most of the residue is related to background levels of copper, it is expected that an MRL of 7 mg/kg (based on the mean plus 4 times the SD), could be sufficient to cover this use.

fn.p: Abbreviations: GAP, Good Agricultural Practice; MRL, maximum residue level; OECD, Organisation for Economic Co‐operation and Development.
Indicates that the MRL is proposed at the limit of quantification of the validated method considered in the MRL review.
NEU: Outdoor trials conducted in northern Europe, SEU: Outdoor trials conducted in southern Europe, EU: indoor EU trials, Country code: if non‐EU trials.
Tentative MRL in the absence of sufficiently validated analytical methods.
